<div class="column">
The Palomarin Field Station, located at the south end of the [Point Reyes National Seashore](https://www.nps.gov/pore/index.htm){target="_blank"}, was established in 1966 and today remains an active field station year-round. Point Blue staff train field biology interns, host organized groups and drop-in visitors, and collaborate on research with agency partners, graduate students, and others. 

With over 50 years of data, the Palomarin Field Station has made unique contributions to the fields of ornithology, ecology, and conservation. Here, you can explore some of the latest data coming from the field station.
</div>

<div class="column">  
[![](../images/icons/nature_stewardship.png "bird icon"){#icon}](banding.html)  

##### [How are the birds doing?](banding.html)  

Explore some of the latest capture stats and how they change over time at one of the oldest, continuously-running banding stations in the United States.  
</div>  
<div class="column">  
[![](../images/icons/climate_change.png "climate icon"){#icon}](climate.html)
  
##### [Tracking a changing climate](climate.html)  

Learn about weather patterns at Palomarin, and how weather and climate change affect bird populations through changes in migration timing, body size, and more.  
</div>  
<div class="column">  
[![](../images/icons/ghg.png "tree icon"){#icon}](habitat.html)
  
##### [Habitat & community change](habitat.html)  

Take a tour of the habitat changes in the Palomarin study area since 1966, and see how the bird community is responding.  
</div>  
<div class="column">  
[![](../images/icons/conservation.png "globe icon"){#icon}](connections.html)

##### [Crossroads & connections](connections.html)  

See how Palomarin is home to birds migrating from thousands of miles away, much like the hundreds of interns who have studied them here, and how we find out where birds come from to inform conservation.
